I’ll be short: an elevator for ships, connecting water channels with different heights. It’s simply a monster elevator, capable of lifting multiple thousands of tons (water + cargo ship + load). The picture is of a Belgian one, but there are tens around the world. What is astonishing to me is a little “hack” that is used to make it work. Ships of any size can pass through it from half ton to 2 thousands tons, and a single ship can be loaded or not. How can this support such wide range of weights? Is it just a powerful engine?  Actually, the engine is capable of much less push and in a much narrower range. It has dead weights, like any other elevator, so that the engine must “just” be able to move a pulley. But the “miracle” is based on a principle well known for thousands of years: Archimedes’ principle. The main tank being lifted contains water other than the ship(s). The water level is always constant as it is the same of the river. So how do the control the weight of the ships entering? Simple: they don’t. Whether one ship, no ships or two fully loaded ships enter, the weight is always constant. How it is so? Because of Archimedes’ principle: the ships will push out as much water as their weight and, since a river can be approximated to “absorb” any quantity of water (i.e. even if the whole amount of water in the tank were poured into the river, the level would not raise as negligible), the water level inside the chamber will stay the same and therefore also the weight. Regardless one, two, one hundred or no ships are inside! In the end it is a simple principle but it is great how this is used to greatly simplify a mechanism that would have been otherwise incredibly clumsy and complicated. If you want to make a simple experiment to prove the mechanism: fill a bucket up to a certain level; mark the level; weigh the bucket. Now put in the bucket a floating object of any given weight (i.e. your ship) and remove as much water as necessary to keep the level at the marker (the river does it automagically). Weigh again. Is the weight any different than before? (hint: it’s not :-) )

In the world of countless technologies, it would be a biased decision to pick just a particular technology. So, I have listed down some of the technologies that are mind-blowing and certainly not many people know about it: #1 Synthetic leaf that produces Oxygen  The synthetic leave is created from a matrix of protein extracted from silk and chloroplasts which absorbs water and carbon dioxide that allows it to perform photosynthesis and hence produce oxygen just like any other plant. It is very light and low energy-consuming. It was developed by Julian Melchiorri, a graduate of the Royal College of Art’s Innovation Design Engineering course, in collaboration with Tufts University silk lab and named it “Melchiorri’s Silk Leaf”. He believes his invention can enable long-distance space travel by producing enough oxygen to breath. #2 Color-changing Contact Lenses for Monitoring Glucose Level  The major issue for a diabetic person is to constantly measure his blood sugar level to avoid any complications related to the disease. But, a diabetic person has to draw a drop of blood in order to do so. However, not with the help of these hydrogel lenses that have nanoparticles which reacts with the glucose molecules present in tears causing the lens to change its colour and thus it can simply tell the individual the rise and drop in sugar levels by the colour of the lens. #3 Transparent Solar Panels  Developed at Michigan State University, made of organic salts that absorb specific non-visible wavelengths. These solar panels use ultraviolet and infrared rays to generate energy and allow the visible light to pass through it. The conventional solar cells absorb the light which creates a shadow as they cannot let the light pass through. But, Transparent Solar Panels doesn’t work the same way as it takes the ultraviolet and infrared light and “luminescent” them as another wavelength of infrared light. Then that infrared light is guided to the other end and collected at the edges where thin strips of conventional photo-voltaic solar cells are present. #4 Personal Neuro Devices  Personal neuro devices are one of the latest inventions that are used to calm a human brain by changing the frequency of the brain waves using electromagnetic impulses. The device can detect the behavior of the brain in different situations and how a person reacts to it. One can choose the state of mind and body that one prefers the most or can allow the device to suggest how the mind should behave. #5 Solar Power Satellite  A solar power satellite (SPS) is capable of storing energy and transmit it to earth via lasers or microwaves. Recently, JAXA (Japanese Aerospace Exploration Agency) had successfully been able to transmit 1.8 kilowatts of energy to an antenna. JAXA is planning on deploying a geosynchronous solar collector weighing 10,000 metric tons at around 36,000 kilometers from Earth. That’s it! Do let me know which of these you found interesting or were familiar with before as well.

Mercedes-Benz promised to come to CES with a vision of the automobile of the future, and the German manufacturer has not disappointed. The new concept, which has been christened the Vision AVTR (for "Advanced Vehicle Transformation"), was developed in direct collaboration with the team responsible for the "Avatar" saga, including its director James Cameron.  The goal, announced by Mercedes, is not only to have the driver merge with the automobile but also to combine the interior and exterior of the vehicle into an "emotional whole," which is in harmony with the surrounding world. With this in mind, the styling of the concept has adopted a design language that Mercedes describes as "organic."  Inside the vehicle, for example, there is no steering wheel but a large centre console that can recognize all of the auto's occupants when they place their hands on it. Via this contact, the concept can take the pulse of all of its passengers and adjust the atmosphere in the interior in accordance. For their part, fans of the film will also appreciate the concept's "immersive experience space," which enables them to directly enter the universe of the saga with images that are projected in 3D.  It should be noted that a multitude of "bionic flaps" reminiscent of reptile scales, which are installed on the roof of the vehicle, is designed to communicate with the driver and "with their outside world through naturally flowing movements," and that the decoration of the passenger compartment is inspired by the Na'vi dwellings in "Avatar."  Finally, in what is perhaps the most surprising innovation, the vehicle, which is equipped with spherical wheels can not only move straight ahead but also laterally and diagonally. As for the engine, Mercedes has opted for a 350 kW motor, offering the equivalent of more than 475 hp, and a range of up to 700 km thanks to the vehicle's innovative graphene batteries.  In short, with the Vision AVTR, it is increasingly difficult to judge where reality ends and fiction begins. Upvotes will be appreciated.

Vagus Nerve Stimulator (VNS). It’s used to help control and prevent epileptic seizures in people who have uncontrolled epilepsy. It’s often referred to as a “pacemaker for the brain”. I had the surgery for this implant last year. I had never heard of it, and I have found that most never have either. Which is a shame, because it’s an amazing piece of technology that should receive more recognition. What it does. The implant sends regular, mild pulses of electrical energy to the brain via the vagus nerve, it’s placed under the skin and attached to the chest wall and a wire runs from it to the vagus nerve in the neck. The vagus nerve is part of the autonomic nervous system, which controls functions of the body that are not under voluntary control, such as the heart rate. The vagus nerve passes through the neck as it travels between the chest and abdomen and the lower part of the brain. The battery/generator usually lasts 5–10 years, or less, depending on your programmed settings. How to use it. A few weeks after surgery (it was about five weeks for me), the device will be programmed by your neurologist or neurosurgeon. It’s programmed to send electrical pulses at regular intervals, such as on for seven seconds and off for five minutes. And, gradually increased until it meets your needs. Then the auto-stimulation is programmed, it’s set to send a higher pulse, and it automatically uses that higher pulse when it senses the beginning of a seizure and when your heart rate spikes a certain percent withing a few nano seconds. Then the magnet settings are programmed, which is used by your friends, family and yourself when a seizure occurs. It’s set at a higher pulse than the auto-stim and often lasts longer. It has helped me quite a bit. It has prevented 20–43 seizures a day. And, as a precaution, I use the magnet on myself three times a day to help keep my brain’s electrical “system” from synchronizing (that’s when seizures occur). My normal cycle is 30 seconds every 90 seconds. My auto-stim cycles 45 seconds. My magnet cycles 60 seconds. All of there electrical pulse settings are different.

Vessyl This is a pretty impressive piece of technology I came across. It is basically a smart-tumbler, and is capable of automatically identifying the beverage inside and measure its nutritional properties with some combination of (currently undisclosed) sensors. For instance, it is able to measure the sugar, protein, fat and caffeine content of coffee and even the calorie count of your own homemade mix. Linked to a large database of known commercial beverages, its accuracy in identifying drinks is remarkable. Harnessing this information, the companion phone/watch application (or the native Health app in iPhone to which it is linked) records and monitors hydration levels and reminds the user to hydrate in order to reach his/her Pryme (the user’s progress to his/her Pryme is also displayed by its characteristic vertical Pryme bar that automatically illuminates in the same familiar fashion as the Apple Watch), a term coined by the makers to represent the optimal levels of hydration. You can read a review by The Verge here: Vessyl is the smart cup that knows exactly what you're drinking.    Although it was originally planned to be released in early 2015, the first release of Vessyl has been delayed. Its sister the Pryme Vessyl, which lacks the smart detection feature, is currently available commercially. It has received some negative reviews and comes at a rather hefty price though. The Pryme Vessyl smart cup is a useless tool for tracking how much water you drink.  Here is the official website of Vessyl.

There is a real jetpack designed by JetPack Technology called the JP-9 that truly lives up to the universal archetype. Unlike the Martin Jetpack which is actually a gasoline powered piston engine that drives ducted fans and is impossible for a wearer to carry, the JB-9 is powered by a real jet engine that is compact and light enough to wear like a backpack and fit in the smallest of car trunks. It made it’s maiden flight around the statue of liberty last November and it was so small, smooth and simple that is was difficult to believe it was real. But it was and is real! Here’s an excerpt from a recent Fortune Magazine article. The JB-9, in contrast to the Martin, runs scaled-down versions of the same kind of jet engines that drive a 747 or F-16. Unlike the old Bell-Williams device, it’s light enough to be carried by a wearer on foot, and small enough to fit into the back seat of a car. The JB-9 also runs on a range of fuels, including diesel and kerosene. Mayman says most of the JB-9’s performance advantages are thanks to recent advances in jet engine technology. There is still that eternal question of the jetpack—how do you not burn your legs? “It’s really not hot,” insists Mayman. “I could fly in shorts.” That’s because the exhaust mixes with ambient air almost immediately. Another advantage of the ‘pure’ jetpack is its performance in high winds and turbulence. “We have no wings, so when we fly into 30 or 40 mile per hour winds, we hardly feel it.” All of that makes the JB-9, at the very least, the first jetpack with potential practical applications. Mayman is particularly keen to see it in the hands of emergency responders, who could travel several miles over rough terrain much more easily than in a helicopter. I don’t think jetpacks will be the future of travel for most of us but it’s a marvel to see it fly. Want to see a piece of the future we were promised for yourself? Here’s some video of the NYC test flight last November.
